comments_text: I would not provide the gym client a superbill. You are seeing her as a trainer, not a PT. If a gym client wants Physical Therapy give her option of home based or office based treatments not at the gym. post_text: I'm a physical therapist looking to connect with others who have partnered with gyms. I'm interested in learning more about how these relationships work, especially in regards to using gym equipment and bringing in non-member clients. Questions: How do you typically structure your partnership with the gym? Are you allowed to bring in clients who are not members? If so, are there any restrictions or limitations? Do you have to prioritize the gym's members over your own clients? What are the benefits and challenges of partnering with a gym?
comments_text: I do not have a private practice but have been researching here and there for a few years. These are great questions, but unfortunately, the answer is not one-size-fits-all. In terms of amenities and business practices, things may differ between gyms, so it‚Äôs essential to know what you want for both your patients and your business. Not allowing non-members would be a major red flag. Everything else can and should be negotiated. If they want member priority, this could be harmful for growth, but you can counter with offering designated member-only times, discounted member rates, asking for lower rent, or requesting marketing support. There is so much ambiguity in this aspect that it will be beneficial to know where you will excel and where you may struggle, so that you ensure the partnership is mutually beneficial and unlikely to lead to future tension. Protect your brand and your values (this is your motivation and drive), ensure a contract is formed (with plenty of reflection and revision), have an exit strategy in writing, and build in a re-negotiation date at a certain checkpoint. As for structure, the most common that you will see are flat rate rent, percentage of revenue, or a hybrid. If you expect very fast growth, then a flat rate may be optimal. If you expect slow growth, a percentage of revenue may be better. A hybrid offers them a guarantee while giving you protection if growth is slow. You could offer a revenue cap where you pay a percentage of revenue up to a certain threshold, followed by a reduction in percentage ‚Äî possibly even to zero. Another option is a tiered split, where the percentage decreases as your revenue increases.

Depends on your agreement/contract with gym. I like percent per visit (can be anywhere 10-30% depending on how everything is set up) rather than flat fee, this gives the gym incentive to send people your way.

post_text: I‚Äôve been connecting with a local DPC/concierge doc, and we want to formally collaborate. We are trying to figure out how to make this work so that I am also getting paid what I am due. comments_text: I love that you‚Äôre thinking through this before you jump in, because the way you structure it now is what‚Äôs going to make this collaboration actually work long term. There are a few clean ways to look at it. First option: treat it like you‚Äôre getting free leads. If she wants to keep her pricing exactly the same and not rearrange anything, that can still work. The big thing is you cannot let people just show up at your door expecting free ongoing PT. You need a 15 minute phone call with them first so you can set expectations clearly‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs what the eval normally costs, here‚Äôs what this first session looks like inside your DPC membership, and here‚Äôs what people with your issue typically need in terms of sessions.‚Äù Basically give it the full discovery call feel so they understand where the free part ends and where your actual plan of care begins. That protects you and makes the whole thing way smoother. Second option: if she‚Äôs planning to raise her prices, then your service can just be baked into that increase. It becomes a value add for her members and she stays whole financially. My guess is she‚Äôs probably not looking to raise prices, but it‚Äôs still worth mentioning because it‚Äôs the most straightforward version of the model. Third option: she pays you directly per person she sends over. If you go this route, compare it to what you‚Äôd normally spend on acquiring a patient. If you‚Äôre running paid ads, depending on your city you might be paying anywhere from $80 to $150 just to get someone on a phone call. These aren‚Äôt cold traffic leads though. These are warm, already-sold referrals coming from someone they trust. That‚Äôs worth a lot. Your conversion rate on those will typically be double what you get from ads. If you frame it that way, you can structure a win-win so every patient who needs PT goes straight to you as the default, not ‚Äúone of several options.‚Äù She sells it as part of the experience. You take it from the first call onward. So you‚Äôve got a few models here. Just make sure whatever you choose sets expectations properly and positions you as the consistent PT solution for her people. That‚Äôs where this kind of relationship becomes genuinely fruitful instead of chaotic.

You have to be careful with these laws -the easiest way is to just accept referrals from the doc : Federal Anti-Kickback Statute (AKS): Prohibits knowingly offering, paying, soliciting, or receiving any remuneration (cash, gifts, discounts) to induce referrals for services paid by federal programs (Medicare/Medicaid). Violations are felonies with severe penalties (prison, fines, exclusion from programs). Stark Law (Physician Self-Referral Law): Prohibits physicians from referring patients for certain services (like lab work, PT, imaging) to entities they or their family have a financial relationship with (ownership or compensation), unless an exception applies. State Laws: Many states (e.g., Texas) have independent anti-solicitation or anti-kickback laws that can be stricter. Professional Ethics: The APA and other organizations specify that payments should be for services rendered, not based on the referral.

If they persist, I‚Äôll take their number and if they reach out, they have a right to stay with someone they‚Äôre comfortable with. Soliciting for a direct competitor at your workplace is really not ok

While a non compete is hard to enforce, you can‚Äôt prevent people from working. Poaching clients is different. That is a non solicitation agreement. Here are some options: Potential legal claims without a non-compete Even if a non-compete agreement is invalid, an employer can pursue legal action against a former employee for "poaching" clients under other legal principles. 1. Breach of fiduciary duty or duty of loyalty During employment: An employee owes a duty of loyalty to their employer. If an employee tries to steal clients while they are still on the company payroll, they can be sued for a breach of this duty. "Corporate opportunity" doctrine: Some courts may view soliciting clients for a competing business during employment as taking an opportunity that rightfully belonged to the employer. 2. Misappropriation of trade secrets Confidential information: If an employee uses confidential or proprietary information, such as a client list, pricing strategy, or internal data, to solicit clients, they can be sued for trade secret misappropriation. Misappropriation laws: The Uniform Trade Secrets Act (UTSA), adopted by most U.S. states, protects companies from employees using trade secrets for their own benefit. 3. Tortious interference Interfering with a contract: An employer can file a claim for tortious interference if a former employee intentionally and improperly disrupts the company's contractual relationships with its clients, causing financial damage. Interfering with a business relationship: This claim is similar to tortious interference with a contract but applies when no formal contract exists. It involves improperly interfering with the company's prospective business relationships.

comments_text: Honestly I‚Äôd look into PWR instead of LSVT- it‚Äôs more adaptable and modifiable to patients. I know a lot of personal trainers teach PWR classes‚Ä¶community word of mouth, no formal referrals

In order to officially offer PWR, LSVT BIG, or Rock Steady, you would need to take the respective courses to get certified. To offer PWR as a non-therapist, you could get certified as an instructor. That track is geared toward the various fitness instructor roles, and can of course also be taken by clinicians. Rock Steady is by default a wellness/exercise based certification. You can get certified as a therapist and could use the ideas in your practice, but you would not be providing the skills of your discipline. It would be a Rock Steady class. As far as I know, there are only clinician certifications for LSVT BIG. There is BIG for Life, though, which may be something other fitness instructors qualify to get certified in. I frankly haven't seen many of those classes, and there's a prerequisite for the patient/client to have already gone through and graduated from a full round of LSVT BIG. ... I am certified in both PWR and LSVT BIG as a clinician. I have a mobile therapy model and rarely use LSVT BIG because it's exhausting to me personally, and because most of my clients would struggle with the intensity due to age, anxiety, orthopedic concerns, etc. I plan to get certified as a PWR Moves Instructor, which is way more focused on building an exercise class. As a therapist, I highly value both PWR certification tracks. (I might also get a personal training cert.) Keep in mind that if you do mobile THERAPY visits, most of these folks have Medicare or a Medicare replacement plan with out of network benefits. Unless you only want to work with YOPD or only want to do exercise classes, I strongly recommend you examine the rules for Medicare billing. The Medicare Billing for (Mostly) Cash Based PT, OT, SLP Providers Group can help with that area.

post_text: This seems so basic, but how do you actually drop off marketing materials to referring clinicians/mds?
comments_text: Something off beat or off the wall like a shock and awe package. Having written a book on your expertise works well, because it takes up physical space on their desk or shelf, but stays subconsciously in the mind. Mail a package of peanuts directly to the doctor with a flyer saying ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd be nuts not to work with us‚Äù A rubber foot saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done the hard work for you and got my foot in the door‚Ä¶now here‚Äôs how we can work with each other to benefit our patients‚Äù If you have a local podcast, getting them on as a guest then opening the 2 way street is a good one.

Here's my process (I'll probably get a million comments saying I'm doing it wrong but....). When I go in, I only bring one form of marketing materials, letter, brochure, card, so I have excuses to come back and drop off more. When I go in, I ask the front desk person their name and if I can drop off materials for the doctor (s). Always respect their level of busy-ness. If they have time for small chitter-chatter while I get out the materials, then that's fine. As soon as I leave the office, I write down the name of the front desk person and any little details they said (going on vacation soon, only work in the mornings, etc). I then put in my calendar when I'll be coming back to drop off more info. On the return visit, I say hello to the front desk person by name and say something about our last conversation (how was your vacation? I came in the morning because I knew you'd be here....) While dropping off different marketing materials from the last time, I try to get some Intel from the front desk (would I be able to schedule a meeting with the doc? How does your office handle PT referrals? Etc). It's a snowball process of getting the trust of the front desk, the gatekeepers. So you can get in to see the MDs face to face.

comments_text: I charge the same rate for everything that I do from physical therapy to a wellness visit. This was good advice given to me a while back. The reasoning is that if you start seeing someone for wellness and charging them one rate and then they tweak their knee and they need you to take care of that, then it‚Äôs difficult to adjust the rate. So i suggest you just stick to one rate for your time‚Ä¶Period. As for your current clients, you could grandfather them in at their current rate, or slightly increased rate, if you‚Äôd like. However, if they take a hiatus from you for any reason, then I would suggest that they return at the current rate.

You also have the option of grandfathering in current clients. If it's only a side hustle and you don't have a full caseload but want to honor and keep current loyal clients, you can raise your price point for new patients but keep your price point for current patients. post_text: Hello there! I want to be uncaged but currently don‚Äôt have the brain power or time to do so‚Ä¶ (mom of a 3 yo and 9 month twins). Can someone shed some light on the whole ‚Äúyou can‚Äôt provide therapy services under cash pay because they‚Äôre billable to Medicare‚Äù thing? Do I have that concept wrong? I see people offering ‚Äúwellness‚Äù rather than therapy. If the above is how it works, aren‚Äôt you by default not providing skilled therapy covered by Medicare if you‚Äôre not documenting your services? There is no skill of a therapist if there is no documented skill of a therapist, and no physician signed POC right? What am I missing here or do I have it all wrong? Thanks for helping me out if you can. I have a few clients in home health that told me they‚Äôd hire me if I started my own practice, but there is absolutely so much I don‚Äôt know and I don‚Äôt have the time to figure it all out üòÖ I‚Äôve just been lurking in here trying to slowly glean information and wrap my head around this concept. Thanks üòä
comments_text: Great question Veronica Erlenbush, and let‚Äôs get some clarity here. The reason why most PT‚Äôs say that you cannot charge cash for Medicare beneficiaries is due to the Meidcare Mandatory Claims Submission Rule. Meaning, if it is skilled PT that Medicare covers, it is mandatory that we submit a claim. Where it gets tricky, is if you have literally no relationship with Medicare, there is no way for you to submit a claim. Here is where it gets confusing: If there is no way to technically submit a claim online, but it‚Äôs still mandatory for you to do it as a non-participating provider‚Ä¶‚Ä¶you can now understand why this is talked about so much lol. Here is where I can give you clarity: Medicare does define wellness as essentially skilled care for the patient. So, if it is unskilled like simple strengthening and endurance, technically that is NOT covered UNLESS a pre-qualifying injury or hospitalization takes place. See where I‚Äôm going here? So, if a Medicare aged client is seeking you out for general strengthening and well-being and they aren‚Äôt being treated for a specific injury or disorder, you can have them sign a Medicare beneficiary form decided under their own free will to pay you out-of-pocket for wellness services. I know it‚Äôs a mess. Honestly, I‚Äôm with PT‚Äôs who have battled this and called it unconstitutional. They have created a monopoly essentially. I believe the only true loophole left, is if they are truly wellness (which the funny thing is that‚Äôs about 90% of HH clients I have seen after they have been discharged from therapy). Then, as long as they are deciding under their own free will because they want to get stronger and pay you, technically they can. You just have to be okay with some physical therapists saying it‚Äôs ‚Äúrisky‚Äù. I believe Medicare has struck immense levels of fear into our profession to try to make sure they keep their monopoly in place. But, if a Medicare aged client who doesn‚Äôt need skilled therapy comes to me and wants to get stronger to age better, I‚Äôll see them 10 out of 10 times.

As a parent, I'll give you parent version. You can't take cash from medicare patient for what would be something medicare pays for. If you a rehabbing a post op knee, can't do it, but if you are keeping them from having pain while playing golf (not a covered service by Medicare) you can.

For BCBS, you need to first log into CAQH and add the location. You can have two locations, so just add your new one, leave the old one as your primary location and then the next time you reattest switch the new one to the primary location and delete the old location. Step 2: log into Availity and go to payer spaces, pick your local Blue Cross, then go to provider enrollment, then choose either individual or group depending on what you are and then select change address and fill out that application.
